forecast.review: Both forecasters emphasize the same core constraints I relied on: a ~53 Elo deficit at the top, only ~2 weeks left, and Elo inertia requiring substantial voting volume. They also highlight the key upside—o3-pro’s fresh release and uncertain strength—and the possibility of fast climbs if a truly superior model hits the Arena quickly. New angles they introduce that I hadn’t weighted much: (1) the narrowing performance spread across the top 10 (they argue this both as tighter competition and as a source of volatility), and (2) OpenAI’s large user base potentially accelerating testing. I’m not convinced the user-base point materially affects Arena’s vote throughput, which is the binding constraint. The “tight field” cut both ways: it may enable leadership rotation with modest performance edges, but it also means more contenders can block OpenAI. Neither forecaster provides concrete signs that o3-pro is/will be on Arena imminently or that early results are exceptional. The argument “OpenAI wouldn’t release a premium model unless it’s highly competitive” is too weak to offset onboarding and time constraints. Overall, their reasoning is sound but doesn’t add decisive evidence that would lift my odds substantially.
forecast.rationale:
Status quo still points to No: Gemini-2.5-Pro leads by ~53 Elo, which is large to overturn in ~16 days without a new OpenAI model on Arena that is clearly superior and can accumulate sufficient votes quickly. Ties count, slightly helping the Yes path, but the onboarding lag and vote volume needed at the very top are the main bottlenecks.

Yes path: o3-pro is added to the Arena within days, shows distinctly higher win rates versus Gemini-2.5-Pro and other top models, and amasses enough matches to reach or tie #1 by July 1. A tie would suffice.

No path: o3-pro is not integrated in time, or it is integrated but doesn’t decisively outperform and/or lacks the vote volume to move 50+ Elo. Alternatively, a non-OpenAI model holds or takes #1 even if Gemini falters.

Why I’m not updating upward: No concrete evidence that o3-pro is live on Arena imminently or that early results are extraordinary. The narrowing top-10 spread increases general volatility but also increases the number of credible blockers to OpenAI being #1 specifically. The Arena’s Elo dynamics at the top, plus the short window, still dominate. 

Why I’m not lowering: Ties count; 2025 has seen leadership turnover; a clearly stronger model can move up rapidly if integrated soon. These keep a nontrivial tail for Yes.

Net: I retain a modest but sub-1-in-3 probability, reflecting a difficult but plausible fast-climb scenario if and only if o3-pro is added and proves clearly superior almost immediately.
